form.longName: Personal And Family History Of Respiratory Symptoms Dise
form.preferredDefinition: This protocol obtains information about the personal history of respiratory symptoms and illnesses. Duration of disease, other allergic diseases, occupational history, smoking status, and family history of selected respiratory diseases are also assessed. Supplemental questions were added from other studies in areas judged to be inadequately covered by this questionnaire.

question.questionText: SYMPTOMS: These questions pertain mainly to your chest. Please answer yes or no, if possible. If a question does not appear to be applicable to you, check the "Does Not Apply" space. If you are in doubt about whether your answer is yes or no, record no.
COUGH Do you usually have a cough? (Count a cough with first smoke or on first going out-of-doors. Exclude clearing of throat.)
COUGH Do you usually cough as much as 4 to 6 times a day, 4 or more days out of the week?
COUGH Do you usually cough at all on getting up, or first thing in the morning?
COUGH Do you usually cough at all during the rest of the day or at night?
COUGH Do you usually cough like this on most days for 3 consecutive months or more during the year?
COUGH For how many years have you had this cough?
COUGH For how many years have you had this cough?
PHLEGM Do you usually bring up phlegm from your chest? (Count phlegm with the first smoke or on first going out-of-doors. Exclude phlegm from the nose. Count swallowed phlegm.)
PHLEGM Do you usually bring up phlegm like this as much as twice a day, 4 or more days out of the week?
PHLEGM Do you usually bring up phlegm at all on getting up or first thing in the morning?
PHLEGM Do you usually bring up phlegm at all during the rest of the day or at night?
PHLEGM Do you bring up phlegm like this on most days for 3 consecutive months or more during the year?
PHLEGM For how many years have you had trouble with phlegm?
PHLEGM For how many years have you had trouble with phlegm?
EPISODES OF COUGH AND PHLEGM Have you had periods or episodes of (increased*) cough and phlegm lasting for 3 weeks or more each year? (*For individuals who usually have cough and/or phlegm)
EPISODES OF COUGH AND PHLEGM For how long have you had at least 1 such episode per year?
EPISODES OF COUGH AND PHLEGM For how long have you had at least 1 such episode per year?
WHEEZING Does your chest ever sound wheezy or whistling: When you have a cold?
WHEEZING Does your chest ever sound wheezy or whistling: Occasionally apart from colds?
WHEEZING Does your chest ever sound wheezy or whistling: Most days or nights?
WHEEZING For how many years has this been present?
WHEEZING For how many years has this been present?
WHEEZING Have you ever had an ATTACK of wheezing that has made you feel short of breath?
WHEEZING How old were you when you had your first such attack?
WHEEZING How old were you when you had your first such attack?
WHEEZING Have you had 2 or more such episodes?
WHEEZING Have you ever required medicine or treatment for the(se) attack(s)?
BREATHLESSNESS If disabled from walking by any condition other than heart or lung disease, please describe Nature of condition(s):
If disabled from walking by any condition other than heart or lung disease, please describe and proceed to CHEST COLDS AND CHEST ILLNESSES Questions.
BREATHLESSNESS Are you troubled by shortness of breath when hurrying on the level or walking up a slight hill?
BREATHLESSNESS Do you have to walk slower than people of your age on the level because of breathlessness?
BREATHLESSNESS Do you ever have to stop for breath when walking at your own pace on the level?
BREATHLESSNESS Do you ever have to stop for breath after walking about 100 yards (or after a few minutes) on the level?
BREATHLESSNESS Are you too breathless to leave the house or breathless on dressing or undressing?
CHEST COLDS AND CHEST ILLNESSES If you get a cold, does it usually go to your chest? (Usually means more than 1/2 the time.)
CHEST COLDS AND CHEST ILLNESSES During the past 3 years, have you had any chest illnesses that have kept you off work, indoors at home, or in bed?
CHEST COLDS AND CHEST ILLNESSES Did you produce phlegm with any of these chest illnesses?
CHEST COLDS AND CHEST ILLNESSES In the last 3 years, how many such illnesses, with (increased) phlegm, did you have which lasted a week or more? Number of illnesses:
CHEST COLDS AND CHEST ILLNESSES In the last 3 years, how many such illnesses, with (increased) phlegm, did you have which lasted a week or more?
PAST ILLNESSES - Lung Trouble Did you have any lung trouble before the age of 16?
PAST ILLNESSES - Bronchitis Have you ever had Attacks of bronchitis?
PAST ILLNESSES - Bronchitis Was it confirmed by a doctor?
PAST ILLNESSES - Bronchitis At what age was your first attack?
PAST ILLNESSES - Bronchitis At what age was your first attack?
PAST ILLNESSES - Pneumonia Have you ever had Pneumonia (include bronchopneumonia)?
PAST ILLNESSES - Pneumonia Was it confirmed by a doctor?
PAST ILLNESSES - Pneumonia At what age did you first have it?
PAST ILLNESSES - Pneumonia At what age did you first have it?
PAST ILLNESSES - Hay fever Have you ever had Hay fever?
PAST ILLNESSES - Hay fever Was it confirmed by a doctor?
PAST ILLNESSES - Hay fever At what age did it start?
PAST ILLNESSES - Hay fever At what age did it start?
PAST ILLNESSES - Chronic Bronchitis Have you ever had chronic bronchitis?
PAST ILLNESSES - Chronic Bronchitis Do you still have it?
PAST ILLNESSES - Chronic Bronchitis Was it confirmed by a doctor?
PAST ILLNESSES - Chronic Bronchitis At what age did it start?
PAST ILLNESSES - Chronic Bronchitis At what age did it start?
PAST ILLNESSES - Emphysema Have you ever had emphysema?
PAST ILLNESSES - Emphysema Do you still have it?
PAST ILLNESSES - Emphysema Was it confirmed by a doctor?
PAST ILLNESSES - Emphysema At what age did it start?
PAST ILLNESSES - Emphysema At what age did it start?
PAST ILLNESSES - Asthma Have you ever had asthma?
PAST ILLNESSES - Asthma Do you still have it?
PAST ILLNESSES - Asthma Was it confirmed by a doctor?
PAST ILLNESSES - Asthma At what age did it start?
PAST ILLNESSES - Asthma At what age did it start?
PAST ILLNESSES - Asthma If you no longer have it, at what age did it stop?
PAST ILLNESSES - Asthma If you no longer have it, at what age did it stop?
PAST ILLNESSES - Other Chest Illnesses Have you ever had Any other chest illnesses?
PAST ILLNESSES - Other Chest Illnesses Please specify chest illnesses you had.
PAST ILLNESSES - Chest Operations Have you ever had Any chest operations?
PAST ILLNESSES - Chest Operations Please specify chest operations you had.
PAST ILLNESSES - Chest Injuries Have you ever had Any chest injuries?
PAST ILLNESSES - Chest Injuries Please specify chest injuries you had.
PAST ILLNESSES - Heart Trouble Has doctor ever told you that you had heart trouble?
PAST ILLNESSES - Heart Trouble Have you ever had treatment for heart trouble in the past 10 years?
PAST ILLNESSES - High Blood Pressure Has a doctor ever told you that you have high blood pressure?
PAST ILLNESSES - High Blood Pressure Have you had any treatment for high blood pressure (hypertension) in the past 10 years?
OCCUPATIONAL HISTORY Have you ever worked full time (30 hours per week or more) for 6 months or more?
OCCUPATIONAL HISTORY - Dusty Job Have you ever worked for a year or more in any dusty job?
OCCUPATIONAL HISTORY - Dusty Job Specify job/industry:
OCCUPATIONAL HISTORY - Dusty Job Total years worked?
OCCUPATIONAL HISTORY - Dusty Job Was dust exposure
OCCUPATIONAL HISTORY - Gas or Chemical Fumes Have you ever been exposed to gas or chemical fumes in your work?
OCCUPATIONAL HISTORY - Gas or Chemical Fumes Specify job/industry:
OCCUPATIONAL HISTORY - Gas or Chemical Fumes Total years worked?
OCCUPATIONAL HISTORY - Gas or Chemical Fumes Was gas or chemical fumes exposure
OCCUPATIONAL HISTORY What has been your usual occupation or job - the one you have worked at the longest? Job-occupation:
OCCUPATIONAL HISTORY What has been your usual occupation or job - the one you have worked at the longest? Number of years employed in this occupation:
OCCUPATIONAL HISTORY What has been your usual occupation or job - the one you have worked at the longest? Position-job title:
OCCUPATIONAL HISTORY What has been your usual occupation or job - the one you have worked at the longest? Business, field, or industry:
TOBACCO SMOKING Have you ever smoked cigarettes? (NO means less than 20 packs of cigarettes or 12 oz. of tobacco in a lifetime or less than 1 cigarette a day for 1 year.)
TOBACCO SMOKING Do you now smoke cigarettes (as of 1 month ago)?
TOBACCO SMOKING How old were you when you first started regular cigarette smoking?
TOBACCO SMOKING How old were you when you first started regular cigarette smoking?
TOBACCO SMOKING If you have stopped smoking cigarettes completely, how old were you when you stopped? Age stopped:
TOBACCO SMOKING If you have stopped smoking cigarettes completely, how old were you when you stopped?
TOBACCO SMOKING How many cigarettes do you smoke per day now?
TOBACCO SMOKING How many cigarettes do you smoke per day now?
TOBACCO SMOKING On the average of the entire time you smoked, how many cigarettes did you smoke per day?
TOBACCO SMOKING On the average of the entire time you smoked, how many cigarettes did you smoke per day?
TOBACCO SMOKING Do or did you inhale the cigarette smoke?
TOBACCO SMOKING Have you ever smoked a pipe regularly? (YES means more than 12 oz. tobacco in a lifetime.)
TOBACCO SMOKING How old were you when you started to smoke a pipe regularly? Age:
TOBACCO SMOKING If you have stopped smoking a pipe completely, how old were you when you stopped? Age stopped:
TOBACCO SMOKING If you have stopped smoking a pipe completely, how old were you when you stopped?
TOBACCO SMOKING On the average over the entire time you smoked a pipe, how much pipe tobacco did you smoke per week? Oz. per week (a standard pouch of tobacco contains 1 1/2 oz.):
TOBACCO SMOKING On the average over the entire time you smoked a pipe, how much pipe tobacco did you smoke per week? Oz. per week (a standard pouch of tobacco contains 1 1/2 oz.)
TOBACCO SMOKING How much pipe tobacco are you smoking now?
TOBACCO SMOKING How much pipe tobacco are you smoking now?
TOBACCO SMOKING Do or did you inhale the pipe smoke?
TOBACCO SMOKING Have you ever smoked cigars regularly? (YES means more than 1 cigar a week for a year.)
TOBACCO SMOKING How old were you when you started smoking cigars regularly? Age:
TOBACCO SMOKING If you have stopped smoking cigars completely, how old were you when you stopped? Age stopped:
TOBACCO SMOKING If you have stopped smoking cigars completely, how old were you when you stopped?
TOBACCO SMOKING On the average over the entire time you smoked cigars, how many cigars did you smoke per week?
TOBACCO SMOKING On the average over the entire time you smoked cigars, how many cigars did you smoke per week?
TOBACCO SMOKING How many cigars are you smoking per week now?
TOBACCO SMOKING How many cigars are you smoking per week now?

validValue.meaningText: Check if not smoking cigars currently

question.questionText: TOBACCO SMOKING Do or did you inhale the cigar smoke?
FAMILY HISTORY Were either of your natural parents ever told by a doctor that they had a chronic lung condition such as: FATHER - Chronic bronchitis?
FAMILY HISTORY Were either of your natural parents ever told by a doctor that they had a chronic lung condition such as: FATHER - Emphysema?
FAMILY HISTORY Were either of your natural parents ever told by a doctor that they had a chronic lung condition such as: FATHER - Asthma?
FAMILY HISTORY Were either of your natural parents ever told by a doctor that they had a chronic lung condition such as: FATHER - Lung cancer?
FAMILY HISTORY Were either of your natural parents ever told by a doctor that they had a chronic lung condition such as: FATHER - Other chest conditions?
FAMILY HISTORY Were either of your natural parents ever told by a doctor that they had a chronic lung condition such as: MOTHER - Chronic bronchitis?
FAMILY HISTORY Were either of your natural parents ever told by a doctor that they had a chronic lung condition such as: MOTHER - Emphysema?
FAMILY HISTORY Were either of your natural parents ever told by a doctor that they had a chronic lung condition such as: MOTHER - Asthma?
FAMILY HISTORY Were either of your natural parents ever told by a doctor that they had a chronic lung condition such as: MOTHER - Lung cancer?
FAMILY HISTORY Were either of your natural parents ever told by a doctor that they had a chronic lung condition such as: MOTHER - Other chest conditions?
Have you ever had wheezing or whistling in your chest?
About how old were you when you first had wheezing or whistling in your chest? Age in years (Answer 1 if younger than age 1 year):
In the last 12 months, have you had wheezing or whistling in your chest at any time?
In the last 12 months, does your chest ever sound wheezy or whistling: When you have a cold?
In the last 12 months, does your chest ever sound wheezy or whistling: More than once a week?
In the last 12 months, does your chest ever sound wheezy or whistling: Most days and nights?
In the last 12 months, have you been awakened from sleep by coughing, apart from a cough associated with a cold or chest infection?
In the last 12 months, have you been awakened from sleep by shortness of breath or a feeling of tightness in your chest?
In the past 12 months, have you been bothered by sneezing or a runny or blocked nose when you did not have a cold or the flu?
In the past 12 months, have you been bothered by watery, itchy, or burning eyes when you did not have a cold or the flu?

In the past 12 months, have you had periods or episodes of cough with phlegm that lasted 1 week or more? (If you usually have cough and phlegm, please count only periods or episodes of increased cough and phlegm.)
For how many years have you had at least one such episode per year?
About how many such episodes have you had in the past 12 months?
In the past year, have you been to the emergency room or hospitalized for lung problems?
How many times?
In the past year, have you been treated with antibiotics for a chest illness?
How many times?
In the past year, have you been treated with steroid pills or injections, such as prednisone or solumedrol, for a chest illness?
How many times?

protocol.longName: Personal and Family History of Respiratory Symptoms/Diseases - Adult Protocol
protocol.preferredDefinition: This protocol obtains information about the personal history of respiratory symptoms and illnesses. Duration of disease, other allergic diseases, occupational history, smoking status, and family history of selected respiratory diseases are also assessed. Supplemental questions were added from other studies in areas judged to be inadequately covered by this questionnaire.

form.longName: Personal And Family History Of Respiratory Sym Child
form.preferredDefinition: Age-specific questions are asked in this protocol to two different age ranges of children. For children ages 13 and 14, a set of questions is asked directly to the child. For children 6 or 7 years old, a set of questions is asked of the parents.

question.questionText: Questionnaire for 13 and 14 year olds
Have you ever had wheezing or whistling in the chest at any time in the past?
Have you had wheezing or whistling in the chest in the last 12 months?
How many attacks of wheezing have you had in the last 12 months?
In the last 12 months, how often, on average, has your sleep been disturbed due to wheezing?

validValue.meaningText: Less than one night per week
One or more nights per week

question.questionText: In the last 12 months, has wheezing ever been severe enough to limit your speech to only one or two words at a time between breaths?
Have you ever had asthma?
In the last 12 months, has your chest sounded wheezy during or after exercise?
In the last 12 months, have you had a dry cough at night, apart from a cough associated with a cold or chest infection?
All questions are about problems which occur when you DO NOT have a cold or the flu.
Have you ever had a problem with sneezing, or a runny or blocked nose, when you DID NOT have a cold or the flu?
In the past 12 months, have you had a problem with sneezing, or a runny or blocked nose, when you DID NOT have a cold or the flu?
In the past 12 months, has this nose problem been accompanied by itchy or watery eyes?
In which of the past 12 months did this nose problem occur? December
In the past 12 months, how much did this nose problem interfere with your daily activities?
Have you ever had hay fever?
Have you ever had an itchy rash which was coming and going for at least six months?
Have you had this itchy rash at any time in the last 12 months?
Has this itchy rash at any time affected any of the following places: the folds of the elbows, behind the knees, in front of the ankles, under the buttocks, or around the neck, ears, or eyes?
Has this rash cleared completely at any time during the last 12 months?
In the last 12 months, how often, on average, have you been kept awake at night by this itchy rash?

validValue.meaningText: Less than one night per week
One or more nights per week

question.questionText: Have you ever had eczema?
Has your child ever had wheezing or whistling in the chest at any time in the past?
Has your child had wheezing or whistling in the chest in the last 12 months?
How many attacks of wheezing has your child had in the last 12 months?
In the last 12 months, how often, on average, has your child's sleep been disturbed due to wheezing?

validValue.meaningText: Less than one night per week
One or more nights per week

question.questionText: In the last 12 months, has wheezing ever been severe enough to limit your child's speech to only one or two words at a time between breaths?

In the past 12 months, has your child had a problem with sneezing, or a runny or blocked nose, when he/she DID NOT have a cold or the flu?
In the past 12 months, has this nose problem been accompanied by itchy, watery eyes?
In which of the past 12 months did this nose problem occur? December
In the past 12 months, how much did this nose problem interfere with your child's daily activities?

Has your child ever had an itchy rash that was coming and going for at least 6 months?
Has your child had this itchy rash at any time in the last 12 months?
Has this itchy rash at any time affected any of the following places: the folds of the elbows, behind the knees, in front of the ankles, under the buttocks, or around the neck, ears, or eyes?
At what age did this itchy rash first occur?
Has this rash cleared completely at any time during the last 12 months?
In the last 12 months, how often, on average, has your child been kept awake at night by this itchy rash?

validValue.meaningText: Less than one night per week

protocol.preferredDefinition: Age-specific questions are asked in this protocol to two different age ranges of children. For children ages 13 and 14, a set of questions is asked directly to the child. For children 6 or 7 years old, a set of questions is asked of the parents.

protocol.preferredDefinition: Exercise testing for evaluation of hypoxemia and/or desaturation

form.preferredDefinition: A trained technician places a sensor on a thin part of the patient's body, usually a fingertip or earlobe, to monitor the oxygenation of the patient's hemoglobin.

question.questionText: Saturation of oxyhemoglobin (SpO2)
Arterial oxyhemoglobin saturation (SaO2)

protocol.preferredDefinition: A trained technician places a sensor on a thin part of the patient's body, usually a fingertip or earlobe, to monitor the oxygenation of the patient's hemoglobin.

form.longName: Quality Of Life As Affected By Respiratory Disease
form.preferredDefinition: Self-administered questionnaire contains 50 items and 76 weighted responses divided into three components: Symptoms (frequency and severity); Activity (activities that cause or are limited by breathlessness); and Impacts (social unctioning, psychological disturbances resulting from airways disease). The protocol is designed to measure health impairment in patients with asthma and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). It is also valid for use in bronchiectasis and has been used successfully in patients with kyphoscoliosis and sarcoidosis.

question.questionText: Questions about how much chest trouble you have had over the past 3 months. (Please tick/check one.) How do you describe your current health?
Over the past 3 months, I have coughed:
Over the past 3 months, I have brought up phlegm (sputum):

How long did the worst attack of chest trouble last?
Over the past 3 months, in an average week, how many good days (with little chest trouble) have you had?
If you have a wheeze, is it worse in the morning?
How would you describe your chest condition?

validValue.meaningText: The most important problem I have
Causes me quite a lot of problems

question.questionText: If you have ever had paid employment.

validValue.meaningText: My chest trouble made me stop work altogether
My chest trouble interferes with my work or made me change my work
My chest trouble does not affect my work

My breathing makes it difficult to do things such as carry heavy loads, dig the garden or shovel snow, jog or walk at 5 miles per hour, play tennis or swim.

Questions about how your activities might be affected by your breathing. My breathing makes it difficult to do things such as very heavy manual work, run, cycle, swim fast, or play competitive sports:

Please write in any other important activities that your chest trouble may stop you doing. Here is a list of other activities that your chest trouble may prevent you doing. (You do not have to tick these; they are just to remind you of ways in which your breathlessness may affect you): Going for walks or walking the dog Doing things at home or in the garden Sexual intercourse Going out to church, pub, club, or place of entertainment Going out in bad weather or into smoky rooms Visiting family or friends or playing with children Please write in any other important activities that your chest trouble may stop you doing:

Which you think best describes how your chest affects you?

validValue.meaningText: It does not stop me doing anything I would like to do
It stops me doing one or two things I would like to do
It stops me doing most of the things I would like to do
It stops me doing everything I would like to do

protocol.longName: Quality of Life as Affected by Respiratory Disease
protocol.preferredDefinition: Self-administered questionnaire contains 50 items and 76 weighted responses divided into three components: Symptoms (frequency and severity); Activity (activities that cause or are limited by breathlessness); and Impacts (social unctioning, psychological disturbances resulting from airways disease). The protocol is designed to measure health impairment in patients with asthma and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). It is also valid for use in bronchiectasis and has been used successfully in patients with kyphoscoliosis and sarcoidosis.

form.preferredDefinition: For infants (15 days to 3 years of age), a study staff member listens to breath sounds via a stethoscope lightly placed on the infant's chest for 60 seconds to count the number of complete respiratory cycles (one inspiration and one expiration). Note that because respiratory rate in infants is significantly different when awake vs. when asleep, studies should be consistent in measuring this variable.

question.questionText: Infants (15 days to 3 years) should be calm, either awake (including quietly seated or quietly playing) or asleep (sleep not associated with any spontaneous movement, including no eye movements or vocalizations). Infants: count breath sounds in a complete respiratory cycle for 60 seconds with a stethoscope gently placed on infant's chest.
Date of Measurement
Infant awake
Number of respiratory cycles in one minute

protocol.preferredDefinition: For infants (15 days to 3 years of age), a study staff member listens to breath sounds via a stethoscope lightly placed on the infant's chest for 60 seconds to count the number of complete respiratory cycles (one inspiration and one expiration). Note that because respiratory rate in infants is significantly different when awake vs. when asleep, studies should be consistent in measuring this variable.

form.preferredDefinition: For children (4 to 16 years of age), a study staff member counts the number of complete respiratory cycles (one inspiration and one expiration) a subject breathes in 60 seconds.

question.questionText: 1) Use a watch which can measure time in seconds. 2) Child (4-16 years of age) should be seated, may be awake or asleep but should be calm, not agitated; observe a complete respiratory cycle and count partial respiratory cycles as complete. 4) Count the number of respirations for 60 seconds or in two separate blocks of 30 seconds each. 5) While counting, note the child's respiratory depth, breathing pattern, and depth of breathing. 6) Record the results
Number of respiratory cycles in one minute
Respiratory depth comments
Breathing pattern comments
Breathing depth comments

protocol.preferredDefinition: For children (4 to 16 years of age), a study staff member counts the number of complete respiratory cycles (one inspiration and one expiration) a subject breathes in 60 seconds.

form.preferredDefinition: A study staff member counts the number of complete respiratory cycles (one inspiration and one expiration) a subject breathes in 60 seconds.

question.questionText: respiratory rate adult intro

1) Use a watch that can measure time in seconds. 2) Place the subject's arm in a relaxed position across his abdomen or lower chest. 3) Observe a complete respiratory cycle (one inspiration and one expiration). 4) Count the number of respiration for 60 seconds. For adults with regular respiratory rhythm, it may be adequate to count for 30 seconds and multiply by two. 5) While counting, note whether depth is shallow, normal, or deep, and whether rhythm is normal or an altered pattern. 6) Record the results.
Respiratory depth comments (shallow, normal, deep)
Breathing pattern comments (rhythm: normal or altered)
Breathing depth comments (shallow, normal, deep)

protocol.preferredDefinition: A study staff member counts the number of complete respiratory cycles (one inspiration and one expiration) a subject breathes in 60 seconds.

form.preferredDefinition: The questionnaire asks about risk factors for sleep apnea, namely snoring behavior, wake time, sleepiness or fatigue, and the presence of high blood pressure. The protocol begins with information that an individual self-reports on height, weight, age, and sex. The 10 questions address snoring, fatigue, and high blood pressure. An algorithm is provided to classify study participants into high or low risk based on response.

question.questionText: Height (m):
Weight (kg):
Age:
Gender:
CATEGORY 1 Do you snore?
CATEGORY 1 Your snoring is:

validValue.meaningText: Very loud can be heard in adjacent rooms

question.questionText: CATEGORY 1 How often do you snore?
CATEGORY 1 Has your snoring ever bothered other people?
CATEGORY 1 Has anyone noticed that you quit breathing during your sleep?
CATEGORY 2 How often do you feel tired or fatigued after your sleep?
CATEGORY 2 During your waking time, do you feel tired, fatigued, or not up to par?
CATEGORY 2 Have you ever nodded off or fallen asleep while driving a vehicle?
CATEGORY 2 How often does this occur?
CATEGORY 3 Do you have high blood pressure?

protocol.preferredDefinition: The questionnaire asks about risk factors for sleep apnea, namely snoring behavior, wake time, sleepiness or fatigue, and the presence of high blood pressure. The protocol begins with information that an individual self-reports on height, weight, age, and sex. The 10 questions address snoring, fatigue, and high blood pressure. An algorithm is provided to classify study participants into high or low risk based on response.

form.preferredDefinition: The Pediatric Sleep Questionnaire (PSQ) protocol is a parent questionnaire for children from 2 through 18 years, and rated on a simple three-point scale ("yes," "no," or "don't know") for all items except the inattention/hyperactivity items that are rated on a four-point Likert scale. This protocol provides an overall total score and five sleep scales: (1) Sleep-Related Breathing Disorders (SRBD), (2) Snoring, (3) Sleepiness, (4) Behavior, and (5) Periodic Limb Movement Disorder (PLMD).

Where are you completing this questionnaire?

Sex:

protocol.preferredDefinition: The Pediatric Sleep Questionnaire (PSQ) protocol is a parent questionnaire for children from 2 through 18 years, and rated on a simple three-point scale ("yes," "no," or "don't know") for all items except the inattention/hyperactivity items that are rated on a four-point Likert scale. This protocol provides an overall total score and five sleep scales: (1) Sleep-Related Breathing Disorders (SRBD), (2) Snoring, (3) Sleepiness, (4) Behavior, and (5) Periodic Limb Movement Disorder (PLMD).

form.preferredDefinition: A spirometric test requires that the subject take a full, deep breath and then exhale as forcefully as possible into a hand-held portable spirometer. The subject's effort is called the forced expiratory maneuver and most commonly measures the amount and speed of air that is exhaled. The total amount (volume) of air exhaled is called the forced vital capacity (FVC). The amount (volume) of air exhaled in 1 second is called the forced expiratory volume in 1 second (FEV1). While hand-held spirometers are commonly used in clinical research studies, the same results can be obtained from more sophisticated floor-mounted devices that are typically available in a respiratory function testing laboratory.

question.questionText: Full protocol is available in the Spirometry Standards PDF, available at: ATS ERS Spirometry Standards (2005)

protocol.preferredDefinition: A spirometric test requires that the subject take a full, deep breath and then exhale as forcefully as possible into a hand-held portable spirometer. The subject's effort is called the forced expiratory maneuver and most commonly measures the amount and speed of air that is exhaled. The total amount (volume) of air exhaled is called the forced vital capacity (FVC). The amount (volume) of air exhaled in 1 second is called the forced expiratory volume in 1 second (FEV1). While hand-held spirometers are commonly used in clinical research studies, the same results can be obtained from more sophisticated floor-mounted devices that are typically available in a respiratory function testing laboratory.

form.longName: Urine Assay For Tobacco Smoke Exposure
form.preferredDefinition:
A biospecimen is collected from the respondent to measure cotinine, a marker of either smoking or of environmental tobacco smoke exposure. One of the most common methods is via a urine sample obtained from the respondent.
Cotinine in urine is measured by gas chromatography mass spectrometry (GC-MS).

question.questionText: The respondent is asked to urinate in a sterile 90-mL urine specimen container. Children above the age of 10 and adults can self-collect the urine. The specimen should be refrigerated immediately after collection. Aliquot 3mLs into a 4 mL cryovial. Freeze the cryovial at -20C until analysis. If the samples need to be stored greater than 1 year, freeze at -80C. Gas chromatography mass spectrometry (GC-MS) is the preferred method to accurately measure cotinine in urine samples. (See source references for details.) The limit of detection is 0.20 ng/mL. A result of 100 ng/mL urinary cotinine or more is indicative of an active smoker.
Concentration of urinary cotinine in ng/mL.

protocol.longName: Urine Assay for Tobacco Smoke Exposure
protocol.preferredDefinition:
A biospecimen is collected from the respondent to measure cotinine, a marker of either smoking or of environmental tobacco smoke exposure. One of the most common methods is via a urine sample obtained from the respondent.
Cotinine in urine is measured by gas chromatography mass spectrometry (GC-MS).

form.preferredDefinition: The female participant uses the Tanner staging drawings to self-assess her breast development and pubertal hair.

question.questionText: Select the option that is closest to your current breast stage.

validValue.meaningText: The nipple is raised a little in this stage. The rest of the breast is still flat.
This is the breast bud stage. In this stage the nipple is raised more than in stage 1. The breast is a small mound. The dark area around the nipple (areola) is larger than in stage 1.
The areola and the breast are both larger than in stage 2. The areola does not stick out away from the breast.

The areola and the nipple make up a mound that sticks up above the shape of the breast. (Note: This stage may not happen at all for some teenagers. Some teenagers develop from stage 3 to stage 5 with no stage 4.).
This is the mature adult stage. The breasts are fully developed. Only the nipple sticks out in this stage. The areola has moved back in the general shape of the breast.

question.questionText: breast stage 1 - image
breast stage 2 - image
breast stage 3 - image
breast stage 4 - image
breast stage 5 - image
Select the option that is closest to your current pubic hair stage.

validValue.meaningText: There is a little long, lightly coloured hair. This hair may be straight or a little curly.
The hair is darker in this stage. It is coarser and more curled. It has spread out and thinly covers a bigger area.
The hair is now as dark, curly, and coarse as that of an adult woman. However, the area that the hair covers is not as large as that of an adult woman. The hair has not spread out to the legs.
The hair is like that of an adult woman. It also covers the same area as that of an adult woman. The hair usually forms a triangular pattern as it spreads out to the legs.

question.questionText: pubic_fem_stage1 - image
pubic_fem_stage2 - image
pubic_fem_stage3 - image
pubic_fem_stage4 - image
pubic_fem_stage5 - image

protocol.preferredDefinition: The female participant uses the Tanner staging drawings to self-assess her breast development and pubertal hair.

form.preferredDefinition: The male participant uses the Tanner staging drawings to self-assess the stage of puberty he has reached in terms of the size and shape of his testes and his pubic hair.

question.questionText: Select the option that is closest to your current stage of physical development.

validValue.meaningText: The size and shape of the testes, scrotum (the sac holding the testes) and penis are about the same as when you were younger.
The penis is a little bit bigger. The scrotum has dropped and the skin of the scrotum has changed. The testes are bigger.
The penis has grown longer, the testes have grown and dropped lower.
The penis is longer and wider. The head of the penis is bigger, the scrotum is a darker colour and bigger. The testes are bigger.
The penis, scrotum and testes are the size and shape of a man's.

question.questionText: penis_stage1 - image
penis_stage2 - image
penis_stage3 - image
penis_stage4 - image
penis_stage5 - image
Select the option that is closest to your current stage of physical development.

validValue.meaningText: There is no hair at all.
There is a little soft, long, lightly coloured hair at the base of the penis. It may be straight or a little curly.
The hair is darker and more curled. It has spread out and thinly covers a bigger area.
The hair is as dark and curly as that of a man, but it hasn't spread out to the legs.
The hair is like that of a man. It has spread out to the legs.

question.questionText: pubic_male_stage1 - image
pubic_male_stage2 - image
pubic_male_stage3 - image
pubic_male_stage4 - image
pubic_male_stage5 - image

protocol.preferredDefinition: The male participant uses the Tanner staging drawings to self-assess the stage of puberty he has reached in terms of the size and shape of his testes and his pubic hair.

form.longName: Causes And Treatments Of Known Infertility Male
form.preferredDefinition: The interviewer asks the participant questions about whether the participant or partner has needed medical assistance with having a baby, the type of assistance, and the type of infertility problems.

question.questionText: Did you or your partner* ever go / Have you or your partner ever been to a doctor or other medical care provider to talk about ways to help you have a baby together?
Which of the services (did / have) you or your / partner* (have / had) to help you have a baby together?
Which other services (did / have) you or your / partner* (have / had) to help you have a baby together?
When you and your partner* went for medical help to have a baby together, were you ever told that you had any of the following male infertility problems?
*Note: The questions have been modified by the PhenX Working Group to indicate partner instead of wife.

protocol.longName: Causes and Treatments of Known Infertility - Male
protocol.preferredDefinition: The interviewer asks the participant questions about whether the participant or partner has needed medical assistance with having a baby, the type of assistance, and the type of infertility problems.

form.preferredDefinition: The interviewer asks the participant questions about whether the participant or partner has needed medical assistance with having a baby, the type of assistance, and the type of infertility problems.

question.questionText: Did you or your partner* ever go / Have you or your partner* ever been to a doctor or other medical care provider to talk about ways to help you have a baby together?

protocol.longName: Causes and Treatments of Known Infertility - Female
protocol.preferredDefinition: The interviewer asks the participant questions about whether the participant or partner has needed medical assistance with having a baby, the type of assistance, and the type of infertility problems.

form.preferredDefinition: Female participants are asked whether they have had a tubal ligation and whether they are able to have children. They are also asked about whether their male partners can have children. Female participants are then asked about the type of birth control they have used in the past and the type they are currently using.

question.questionText: Have you ever had both of your tubes tied, cut, or removed? This procedure is often called a tubal ligation or tubal sterilization. (ASKED IF RESPONDENT (R) IS NOT CURRENTLY PREGNANT)
Have you ever had any other operation that makes it impossible for you to have (a/another) baby?

Many women who have only one (tube tied/ovary removed) can still have babies because they are not completely sterile. As far as you know, are you completely sterile from this operation, that is, does it make it impossible for you to have a baby in the future?
Has (HUSBAND/PARTNER) ever had a vasectomy or any other operation that would make it impossible for him to father a baby in the future?
What type of operation did (HUSBAND/PARTNER) have?
As far as you know, is he completely sterile from this operation, that is, does it make it impossible for him to father a baby in the future?
Have you ever used birth control pills?
Have you ever used oral contraceptives for two months or more for any reason (contraception, acne, menstrual irregularity, etc.)?
How old were you when you began using oral contraceptives?
For how long in total have you used oral contraceptives?

validValue.meaningText: More than one year but less than ten years

question.questionText: Have you ever used condoms or rubbers with a partner?
Have you ever had sex with a partner who had a vasectomy?
Have you ever had sex with a partner who used withdrawal or "pulling out"?"
(Have you ever used) Depo-Provera or injectables (or shots)?
(Have you ever used) Norplant (implants)?
Have you ever used rhythm or safe period by calendar to prevent pregnancy?
(Have you ever used) Natural family planning or safe period by temperature or cervical mucus test to prevent pregnancy?

protocol.preferredDefinition: Female participants are asked whether they have had a tubal ligation and whether they are able to have children. They are also asked about whether their male partners can have children. Female participants are then asked about the type of birth control they have used in the past and the type they are currently using.

form.preferredDefinition: The interviewer asks the participant questions about whether she/he and male/female partner are trying to become pregnant. If the participant answers that she/he and her/his partner are trying to become pregnant, the interviewer asks how long they have been trying.

question.questionText: Are you and (PARTNER'S NAME) currently trying to get pregnant?
How long (how many months) have you and (PARTNER'S NAME) been trying to get pregnant?

protocol.preferredDefinition: The interviewer asks the participant questions about whether she/he and male/female partner are trying to become pregnant. If the participant answers that she/he and her/his partner are trying to become pregnant, the interviewer asks how long they have been trying.

form.preferredDefinition: The participant answers a question about whether she has had a hysterectomy. If so, she answers a question about whether she has also had any ovaries removed and if so, at what age.

question.questionText: Have you had a hysterectomy (womb removed)?

protocol.preferredDefinition: The participant answers a question about whether she has had a hysterectomy. If so, she answers a question about whether she has also had any ovaries removed and if so, at what age.

form.preferredDefinition: Female participants answer questions about when menstruation began and when they reached full height.

question.questionText: How old were you when your menstrual periods began?
At about what age did you reach your full height?

protocol.preferredDefinition: Female participants answer questions about when menstruation began and when they reached full height.
